titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Sent my book-case and some books to the office I have taken in State-Street— Mrs: Wilson, Mrs: Doble and Mr: Boylston call’d to visit us— Sundry purchases— Dined with Mr: John Codman— A large company of Gentlemen. Mrs: and the two Miss Codman’s the only ladies— Evening at Mr: Smith’s— Mr: Storer, his daughters and Dr: Welsh with the ladies of his family were there.

2. Mr: Howard called this forenoon— I was busied in arrangements to enter my office— Judge Minot very ill. Met Quincy and had some conversation with him— Declined his proposition— Called on Mrs: Shaw, to enquire the character of a servant— On T. Amory, and gave him to send to France the duplicate of my letter to Mr: Livingston, with the enclosure for Genl: La Fayette— Immediately after dinner, came out to Quincy, with my wife and child— Road uncommonly rough and bad— Reached my father’s house just at dark— Found Captn: Beale there. He stay’d all the evening.

3. I was up very early this morning, and engaged the whole day in setting papers to rights— The hours of public worship however excepted, which I attended, morning and afternoon. My wife was unwell all day; and in the evening quite ill.

4. It rain’d and storm’d so much the whole day, that we were unable to go into town— My Uncle Adams and Mr: Black called in the morning— About a question concerning the settlement of certain poor— Boylston Adams in the evening came and consulted me about a claim he has to certain lands— Pass’d the greatest part of the day in the office, arranging papers and reading The Baviad.

5. Cleared up in the night, and the weather became severely cold.— We came into town; I took possession of my office in the afternoon— Called at the Bank, and received my dividend upon 8. per Cents. Evening at home.

6. Weather soften’d down again— Judge Minot, who died on the 2d: was buried this afternoon— I attended his funeral— In the evening, attended the club at Mr: Smith’s— Found J. Welles there— The conversation principally upon Mr: Minot’s sudden decease.

7. Mr: B. Shaw sent for me this morning— Mr: Shaw had been very ill all night and wanted me to draw up some writings— I went, found Dr: Jarvis there— But Mr: Shaw appeared to be in no immediate danger— And postponed the drawing of his papers to a future opportunity— Paid Fitch Hall 3. assessments upon the Middlesex Canal.— Went Before dinner with Quincy to Mr: Popkin’s but he was not at home— Read a little law and began attending to business— At 7. in the evening I went with Quincy to the meeting of the Society to pursue subjects of Natural philosophy— Newly instituted and to consist only of ten members— Signed their Articles and attended the experiments and observations. N. Frazier was the lecturer, and magnetism the subject— The text book is Jones’s edition of Adams’s lectures upon natural and experimental philosophy— By the rules, the lectures commence at 7. in the eveg: and close at 10.

8. My Uncle Adams and his son Boylston, called on me, the former at my Office, the latter at my house, respecting Boylston’s claim mentioned some days ago. Spent the principal part of the day at my office. Called in at the Court of Common Pleas after dinner— Evening at home— The commencement of my old profession again, is attended with difficulties somewhat embarrassing, and prospects not very encouraging— But I thank God, I can yet struggle with the ills of life allotted to me.

9. Spent the principal part of the day at my Office, examining some of the points upon which my opinion is required— Mr: Snow called at my office, and desired me to proceed in the action of Brookins— The child unwell this afternoon— Sent for Dr: Welsh, who came and saw him— Unpack’d a chest of my books in the evening; but have no place to put them in.— Much stinted for want of room.

10. Up very early this morning. Weather stormy with heavy rain. In the afternoon it cleared up very cold. Mrs: Knox and her daughter came and visited Mrs: Adams— In the forenoon I went to the Old Brick Meeting-house, where Mr: Emerson is now the successor of Dr: Clarke— Heard Dr: Thacher. In the afternoon, went to the chapel church, and heard Mr: Freeman’s funeral elogy, upon the friend and companion of his youth and childhood, judge Minot— It was solemn, instructive and pathetic— Spent the evening at home, principally in reading the Voyage dans la Haute Pensylvanie.

11. At the probate Office, and registry of deeds, upon Boylston Adams’s business— Natl: Beale, and Mr: Townsend at my Office— Attended the meeting of the Union Bank Stockholders— The business to petition for a continuance of the charter of incorporation— Dr: Welsh called at my Office, and hinted to me the probability that judge Dawes, would quit the Bench of the Supreme Court, to take the Offices of probate and municipal judge, and that I might be nominated to supply his place— I afterwards saw Dr. Welsh again, and told him that I hoped the nomination would not be made, as if it were, I should be obliged from a variety of considerations to decline accepting it.— Mr: Shaw dined with us— Spent the afternoon at my Office, and the evening at home—reading to Mrs: Adams, in Locke’s treatise upon Education.

12. Called again at the Offices of Register of Deeds, and of probate— Found some documents to my purpose, in the former—none in the latter— Mrs: Codman called to see Mrs: Adams; and D. Sargent on me— As did Mr: Babcock, upon business—to retain me in certain insurance causes upon the ship Martha— Afternoon at my Office, and evening at home— Mrs: Adams unwell with a head ache.

13. Called this morning upon Mr: Boylston, but he was not at home— Upon Mr: T. Parsons and had a couple of hours conversation with him— Went with Mrs: Adams to visit Mrs: Knox, Mrs: Jonn: Amory junr: Mrs: R. Amory, Mrs: Wilson & Mrs: Doble and Miss Allen. Saw only the two first. Made some calculations upon the increase of population in the United States— At my office in the afternoon— Spent the evening and supped at Mr: R. Amory’s, with a company of about twenty persons.— Genl: & Mrs: Knox; Mr: & Mrs: Morton, Mrs: Hichborn, Mr: & Mrs: Callender, Mr: & Mrs: Apthorp, Mr: Sheriff Allen, Mr: Escher a Hamburger— Mr: Andrews, (a son of Mrs: Hichborn) Mr: & Mrs: Winthrop, Mr: D. Sears &c— It was almost midnight when we came home—weather cold and fair.

14. Attended the Court of Common Pleas, but no trials came on in the course of the day. Mrs: Adams sent an excuse for not going this evening to the Ball— Read in the forenoon the chapter of Abandonment in Parke— In the afternoon the Imperial epistle of Kien Long to George 3. and in the evening, continued Locke, upon Education.

15. Saw Mr: Jackson this morning, who promised me some money for 8 per cts: to-morrow morning— Afterwards saw Dr: Tufts— Went with Dr: Parker to Franklin place, and look’d over the house for which I have been in Treaty with him, as Executor to Mrs Howard— Agreed to take the house at 6500 dollars.— To pay him 2000 at the Execution of the deeds, and. the remainder on the 1st: of next June.— Dined, with Mr: W. Payne and his sisters. Mrs: Amory the old lady, with Messrs: J. Welles, T. Amory, James Perkins, and J. Callender and their wives. Jonn: Davis and his wife. J. T. Sargent and Countess Rumford were there— In the evening I attended the meeting of the Society for the study of natural philosophy— Frazier continued to read—the subject still magnetism. Quincy was called home before we adjourned.

16. At length after a month of waiting, I sold to John Jackson, broker 3000 dollars of 8. per ct: stock. Went with him to the loan-office, and transferr’d 1000 dollars of them to Peter Folger of Nantucket, and the remainder to him.— He paid me the money by a check on the Union Bank, which I immediately received.— Paid Mr: Cleland my note to him, with interest— Dined at J. Callender’s, with a company of fourteen or fifteen gentlemen. Captain Wilson of Baltimore there— Home early in the evening.— Weather again uncommonly mild.— The town sickly— An inflammatory sore throat prevailing, which in many instances has proved fatal: its operation very rapid.

17. Heard Mr Emerson preach in the forenoon, and President Willard in the afternoon.— Called in at Mr: Smith’s for half an hour, after meeting. General Knox called with W. Shaw to pay us a visit. Eveg: at home.

18. Called this morning on Mr: Morrill, to enquire concerning a house in Newbury Street— Mr: Soley the owner came to my office— My mother came into town with Louisa Smith and Susan, and dined with us— They went out to Quincy again after dinner— Bought of Dr: Parker Exor: of Mrs: Howard, her house in Franklin place N: 13.— Gave him my bond and mortgage for part of the money to pay 1. June next— Mr: Stevenson acknowledged the deeds, and with Mr: Jos: Russell witnessed them— Mr: J. R. Greene is to hold the house untill 1. June 1803. and Dr: Parker answers to me for the rent— I carried both deeds to the register’s office, for record— Went with Mrs: Adams to pass the evening at Dr: Welsh’s— There was a fire, which burnt down two houses upon Fort-hill— I went to it— There appeared to me a want of order and of proper engines, in the means of extinguishment, used— Eliz: Smith, came home to her brother’s with Mrs: Adams.

19. Mr: Soley called upon me this forenoon— I went with him to look at the house he has for sale— Found it would not suit me. Went to hear the debates in the house of Representatives at the new State-house.— They were upon the subject of building a new State prison.— Called at Captain Scott’s, and saw the Ladies there— Mrs: Scott, Mrs: Sheaffe and Miss Quincy— Mrs: Beale and her daughter were also there— Mrs: Adams return’d a number of visits— In the afternoon, at my Office— Walked in the mall— In the evening there was a fire, on one of the wharves which consumed a blacksmith’s and a carpenter’s shop— I attended and gave what aid I could to extinguish— In the night between 12 and 1. we were again rous’d from sleep by a cry of fire upon the long wharf, which was however immediately extinguished.

20. Great part of the forenoon employed upon family concerns— The remainder at my office— And the afternoon. Spent the evening at the club; at Dr: Warren’s— Mr: John Vaughan there— Mrs: A— pass’d the evening with Mrs: Smith.

21. Forenoon at my office— Reading Park on Insurance, and making some observations on Mr: Sullivan’s history of Land-titles. Dined with Mr: Allen, the Sheriff; a company of Gentlemen and Ladies— Mr: and Mrs: Knox, Parkman, Coolidge, Jonn: Amory, Mrs: Sheaffe and Mr: Sheaffe—Captn: Scott, Countess Rumford, Mr: & Mrs: Hichborn &c. Pass’d the evening with the Society for the study of natural philosophy— But it was a very stormy night, and Frazier who was our lecturer for the evening did not appear— We spent the time therefore in general conversation; and agreed to change our weekly evening from Thursday to Friday.

22. Went to the State-house this morning at Quincy’s request to attend the Committee upon the petition for a bridge over the Neponsit river. But they did not sit; and have postponed their meeting untill next Wednesday— Remainder of the day at my Office— Mr: Smith called and left a letter on business from Mr: Pitts— Began reading Park on Insurance— Walk in the Mall— Spent the Evening at Mr: Smith’s, with a company of ladies and gentlemen.— Weather grew cold towards night.— I likewise began this morning, before breakfast, upon George Adams’s lectures on experimental philosophy— A subject to which I purpose now to pay attention.

23. Mr: Smith called at my office this forenoon with a letter from Mr: Pitts relative to an estate left by Mr: John Boylston of Bath, for certain charitable purposes— My fathers carriage came into town, and in the afternoon we went out to Quincy— Mr: Shaw came to stay in the house during my absence.

24. The weather more severely cold than it has yet been this winter— Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day. Read one of Adams’s lectures— My uncle Adams, with his son Boylston and his wife, dined at my father’s. Boylston was married the 21st.— He was again here in the evening, with his brother in Law Bass, to consult with me respecting their claim upon Belcher’s lands, which I advised them to abandon— I went with my father and spent part of the evening at Mr: Black’s.

25. Fahrenheit’s thermometer this morning at 7. o’clock, was at 4 degrees above 0. But in the course of the day the weather moderated. My wife is to spend the week at Quincy. I attempted to get a seat in the stage from Plymouth, but it was full of passengers— Dexter then took me as far as Roxbury, and from the fourth milestone I walk’d into Boston— Called at my Office for half an hour and spent the remainder of the evening alone at home.

26. Mr: Smith called at my Office this forenoon with Mr: Boylston’s will and the letters between him and Mr: Gill which I read— Mr: Ames spoke to me concerning Mr: Babcock’s cause, he being engaged with me in it. In the
afternoon, I walk’d in the mall— Evening at home, alone— H. Townsend likewise called on me this forenoon, at my office— And J. Gardner.

27. My father came to town— I attended with him a meeting of the Academy of Arts and Sciences: at the State-house— Mr: Dearborn presented his scale and his windmill— A Committee of publication chosen— My father, J. Quincy and Shaw dined with me— My father return’d to Quincy in the afternoon— At my Office, a short time— Evening with the club at Mr: J. Welles’s— Went with Mr: W. Smith.

28. The day, chiefly at my office— In the forenoon reading Park, and in the afternoon the British critic— Evening at home, alone— Studying G. Adams on air, and chimney fire places— Walk’d in the mall just before night— I feel strong temptation and have great provocation to plunge into political controversy— But I hope to preserve myself from it, by the considerations which have led me to the resolution of renouncing.— A politician in this Country must be the man of a party— I would fain be the man of my whole Country.— Mr: Isaac Smith called upon me in the morning.

29. Mr: Boylston and Mr: W. Smith called at my office in the forenoon— J. Phillips in the afternoon. Phillips was desirous of information whether I would accept the office of Judge at the Supreme Court of this State, vacant by the resignation of Mr: Dawes, who is appointed to the probate and municipal offices— But he did not tell me what was the motive for his curiosity. He said he had heard only three persons mentioned— Sedgwick— Thomas of Plymouth and me.— I told him that if the Governor, or any member of the council whose vote was to concur in the appointment wish’d to know my resolution, they might know it, by applying either personally or by any friend directly to me— That I would tell him, I did not want the place; and wished that no friend of mine would move a finger to obtain it for me— But that it would be ridiculous for me to tell any body and every body that I would or would not accept an office which there might be no thoughts of offering me— In the evening I attended the meeting of the Society, which for the want of an apparatus, again pass’d off in miscellaneous conversation; with a few additional magnetical experiments.

30. Forenoon at my Office, casting up the amount of Mr: Pitts against Mr: Gill’s estate. W. Shaw dined with me, and we then went out to Quincy, with Mr: Black, whom we took up at Mr: Clap’s— The ladies when we reached Quincy, were out, but soon came home.

31. The month of January closes like a day in Spring— The weather has hitherto been unusually mild through the winter, thus far— Heard Mr: Whitney preach morning and afternoon— His subject was the reproof of anger. In the evening, my Uncle Adams, Boylston and his wife and sister and Mr: & Mrs: Whitney visited us.

Day— I rise very irregularly, from 4 to 7. o’clock— Make my fire, bring up my accounts and this journal for the preceding day, and read in Adams’s lectures upon experimental philosophy, till 9—breakfast; attend to my necessary domestic details till 11. Spend from that time till 2. p.m. at my office, upon business, or in reading law— Home to dinner— Return to my Office at 1/2 past 3. Stay there untill dark— Walk an hour in the Mall; pass the evening untill 10— At home, at the club, at the Society, or in company— A-bed between 10 and 11.— Saturdays, in the afternoon I come to Quincy; and Monday mornings return to Boston— An object of urgent reform is my mode of study, and the practice of whiling away time— For the power of commanding the application of my own mind, I can only pray to Heaven. During the course of the present year, I shall undertake to do, little or nothing— My object will be to learn. It is late, in the progress of my life to complete my education, and perhaps after my age, a man can learn but little— Yet must I not despair.
